DOCNAME: CASE OF NOLAN AND K. v. RUSSIA
CONCLUSION: Violation of Article 38 - Examination of the case-{general} (Article 38 - Obligation to furnish all necessary facilities);Violation of Article 9 - Freedom of thought, conscience and religion (Article 9-1 - Freedom of religion;Manifest religion or belief);Violation of Article 8 - Right to respect for private and family life (Article 8-1 - Respect for family life);Violation of Article 5 - Right to liberty and security (Article 5-1 - Lawful arrest or detention);Violation of Article 5 - Right to liberty and security (Article 5-5 - Compensation);Violation of Article 1 of Protocol No. 7 - Procedural safeguards relating to expulsion of aliens (Article 1 para. 1 of Protocol No. 7 - Expulsion of an alien;Lawfully resident);Non-pecuniary damage - award (Article 41 - Non-pecuniary damage;Just satisfaction)
JUDGES: Anatoly Kovler;Christos Rozakis;Dean Spielmann;Elisabeth Steiner;Khanlar Hajiyev;Sverre Erik Jebens
TEXT: CARDINAL . Mr PERSON and PERSON were born in DATE and DATE respectively and live in GPE , GPE . PERSON is the father and sole custodial parent of PERSON
CARDINAL . Since DATE the applicant has been a member of ORG ( “ the NORP ” ) , a spiritual movement founded by Mr PERSON in DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG was officially registered as a religious association in the NORP Socialist GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of GPE granted ORG re - registration to ORG at federal level as a centralised religious organisation . It did so on the basis of an expert opinion from ORG , which stated , inter alia , the following :

“ In GPE neither ORG nor its leaders have ever been held criminally liable . No violations of the federal law on freedom of conscience and religious associations on the part of ORG or its various representatives have been established . Thus , ( CARDINAL ) ORG is a religious , non - commercial organisation and , accordingly , has the characteristics of a religious association within the meaning of section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the federal law on freedom of conscience and religious associations ; and ( CARDINAL ) no indication of unlawful activities has been uncovered in its religious teachings and corresponding practice . ”

CARDINAL . In DATE the ORG invited the applicant to assist its activities in GPE . ORG of GPE granted the applicant leave to stay in GPE . His leave to stay was subsequently renewed by ORG on a yearly basis through invitations issued by the registered religious organisation of ORG in GPE and an associated social organisation in GPE , ORG ) .

CARDINAL . The applicant lived primarily in PERSON - on - Don in southern GPE , where he worked with local branches of the FFWPU and ORG ( ORG ) . He explains that , while ORG , the FFWPU and the ORG and other associations operating in GPE maintain legal independence from one another , they cooperate with one another in pursuit of similar goals . According to the applicant , these organisations acknowledge their origin in ORG founded by PERSON ; their different titles and legal forms reflect the specific focus of their activities and the fact that the social organisations are open to members of other faiths .

CARDINAL . On DATE the FFWPU established a local organisation in GPE . Since the applicant ’s host organisation in GPE was responsible for processing his residence registration with the police during the term of his stay , this was subsequently arranged through GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the acting President of GPE amended , by Decree no . DATE , ORG , adopted in DATE . The relevant paragraph of LAW , “ Ensuring the National Security of the GPE ” , was amended to read :

“ Ensuring the national security of GPE also includes the protection of its ... spiritual and moral heritage ... the forming of a ORG policy in the field of spiritual and moral education of the population ... and also includes opposing the negative influence of foreign religious organisations and missionaries ... ”

CARDINAL . On DATE the Promyshlenniy ORG of Stavropol , on an application by the acting PERSON regional prosecutor , decided to dissolve the PERSON regional branch of the FFWPU and ban its activities “ irrespective of ORG registration ” on the ground that it was “ engaged in religious activities under the guise of a registered social organisation ” . On DATE ORG upheld the judgment of DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG newspaper ran an article on ORG activities in southern GPE which DATE according to the applicant – described in general terms the grounds subsequently endorsed by ORG in favour of his expulsion . It was entitled “ Caramels from PERSON will drive to debility ” ( « ‘ Гуцулочки’ от PERSON до маразма доведут PERSON ) :
“ The prosecutor ’s office of LOC has banned the activity of social organisations under the protection of which the NORP PERSON ... was buying souls for $ MONEY a piece .
Once there were CARDINAL public organisations registered by ORG : ORG ( ORG ) and ORG ) . As it turned out , these so - called public movements preach one of the most dangerous religions of DATE ...

Outwardly inoffensive ‘ ORG who sell or give away the ‘ GPE newspaper and cheap caramels lure young men and women into PERSON ’s family ... PERSON missionaries who were freely permitted to lecture to senior students at PERSON schools introduced themselves as volunteers from ORG ( ORG ) , [ which is ] CARDINAL of PERSON ’s many ‘ parishes’ ...

The self - proclaimed lecturers had no documents authorising them to talk to students . To ‘ sweeten’ the lectures , they distributed caramels . Later , a panel of experts from the PERSON clinic for borderline states gave a negative appraisal of ORG caramels that Moonies distributed to children and adults alike . As it turned out , an outwardly inoffensive caramel destroys the human being ’s energy - information profile . Simply speaking , such caramels with little - known inclusions – in some of them small holes are visible – facilitate the conversion of neophytes into zombies .

The contents of PERSON lectures leave a strong aftertaste of debility . It is sufficient to read the briefing materials [ prepared by ] the ORG DATE an outline of the lecture on ‘ Preparation of a GPE . Citation : ‘ The genitals belong to a spouse and they only serve their purpose in a marital relationship ... Until the marriage you are the guardian of your genitals for your future spouse ... ’

After some time ... [ a certain young man ] was introduced to the head ORG in LOC , PERSON . To the newcomers he was presented as an NORP professor who periodically came to them from PERSON - on - Don ...

In GPE , a mass of associations belong to the ORG movement DATE professors , women and even mass - media employees , including cultural foundations and the aforementioned ORG and FFWPU . All these socialites are preachers of ORG . Meanwhile , DATE the [ upper chamber of ORG ] declared ORG a totalitarian sect and a destructive cult ...

At long last the prosecutor ’s office and ORG of LOC have started working on the Moonies . The regional prosecutor has filed an application ... for dissolution of the ORG and banning of its activities . The same goes for the FFWPU ...

CARDINAL question is still open : why does such a tenacious businessman as PERSON spend [ resources ] on NORP ? There are several theories . Not long ago ... addresses were confiscated from one GPE ... Among them – the address of an NORP , PERSON , who passes his time in PERSON , and CARDINAL e - mail addresses of the ORG . Why should n’t we imagine that PERSON ’s aim ... is to catch our homeland in a spy net consisting of CARDINAL of agents – teachers , scholars , engineers , students and servicemen ... ? ” [ italics as in the original ]

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant ’s leave to stay in GPE was renewed for DATE by ORG on the basis of an invitation from the FFWPU . As before , the applicant registered his residence with the police upon arrival in GPE , through the GPE branch of the FFWPU .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant ’s son , PERSON , was born . On DATE the applicant and his wife separated ; the applicant ’s wife returned to GPE and the applicant retained sole custody of the child .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG of GPE - on - Don , on an application by ORG , decided to dissolve PERSON on the ground that it had failed to notify the registration authorities of the continuation of its activities for DATE . According to the applicant , by that time GPE had been incorporated for DATE and had been issued with a new registration certificate by ORG just DATE previously , after undergoing re - registration . According to the judgment , the Rostov FFWPU was incorporated on CARDINAL DATE or DATE , both dates being mentioned as the incorporation date . The hearing was held in the absence of both parties and the ORG learned of the decision after it had come into force on DATE , with no further right of appeal .

CARDINAL . On DATE the GPE police summoned the applicant and demanded his passport . They added a stamp to the effect that his registration was “ terminated ” , orally notifying him that the Rostov FFWPU had been dissolved by a court order .

CARDINAL . Thereafter the applicant obtained registration with the police through other FFWPU branches , first in PERSON and then in GPE . His residence registration in PERSON was valid for the entire term of his leave to stay under his current visa , that is , until DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant travelled to GPE . His son stayed in GPE with his nanny .

CARDINAL . At TIME on DATE the applicant arrived at FAC in GPE on a flight from GPE . When he reached the passport control booth , CARDINAL officers – CARDINAL male and the other female – examined his passport and visa insert . The male officer left with his documents , while the other told him to wait .

CARDINAL . At TIME on DATE the applicant was allowed to cross the border to collect his baggage . Border officials conducted an extensive search of his belongings . Then he was directed back through passport control and out through the passenger entry doors from the tarmac to a flight transfer bus , which took him to the airport transit hall .

CARDINAL . Upon his arrival at the transit hall , officials directed the applicant to wait in a small room adjacent to their office with a desk and a sofa , but no phone , ventilation or windows . Once he entered the room , the officials locked him in from outside . Initially the applicant thought that this would be just for TIME , but after TIME he realised that he was being held in an improvised detention cell . He began knocking on the door , asking to be let out . The female officer responded through the door that he would not be let out until TIME , and told him to lie down and sleep . TIME after that a male officer came with the applicant ’s visa stapled to a CARDINAL - page document . He told the applicant that his visa had been cancelled and asked him to sign the document . The applicant did as he was requested , although he could not read the document , which was handwritten in NORP .
CARDINAL . At TIME , after knocking and shouting for TIME , the applicant was allowed to leave under guard and use the toilet .

CARDINAL . At TIME a man in civilian clothing came to the room and introduced himself as the official in charge of passport control officers . The applicant was told that he would not be allowed to cross the NORP border and that border officials were only following orders and were not responsible for the decision . The man said that he did not know the reason for the decision and could not disclose where the order had come from . The man apologised that the applicant had been held TIME in the room , stating that “ the night crew is not too bright ” .

CARDINAL . The applicant bought a ticket to GPE , GPE . A border guard continued to accompany the applicant until he boarded his flight at TIME , returning his passport , but not his visa , only before he entered the aeroplane .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant sent letters , through his legal representatives in GPE , by registered mail to :
- the Ministry of Foreign Affairs ;
- ORG ( ORG ) and its department in GPE ;
- ORG , the military prosecutor ’s office of that service and ORG ;
- the Ministry of the ORG and its FAC department of passports and visas ; and
- the ORG and Presidential Envoy for ORG .

CARDINAL . In these letters the applicant asked why he had been denied entry and detained even though he had committed no violation and why no procedural documents had been compiled or given to him . He also complained that he had been detained for TIME , and that as a result of the exclusion his DATE son had been left behind in GPE without either of his parents . The applicant also requested assistance to be reunited with his son .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant received a new invitation issued through ORG . On DATE he applied for a visa to enter GPE at the NORP consulate in GPE and on DATE he was issued a multiple - entry visa valid until DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE , while he was crossing the border from GPE to GPE , NORP border guards at passport control twice stamped the applicant ’s visa “ annulled ” and denied him entry into GPE . No explanation was given . The consulate in GPE referred him to the ORG ’s office in GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was reunited with his son whom his nanny , a NORP national , had brought to GPE .

CARDINAL . Many of the applicant ’s complaints sent on DATE did not receive a response . Of those that did , none addressed the substance of his complaints . Responses from ORG of ORG of DATE and CARDINAL DATE indicated that he had been denied entry into GPE on the basis of section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW , in implementation of an order given by another ( unnamed ) State body . The military prosecutor ’s office responded that the applicant “ had not been placed in administrative detention and therefore no detention record had been drawn up ” .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant , through his legal representative in GPE , challenged the decision refusing his return to GPE before the ORG of LOC . He filed the challenge on behalf of himself and his son PERSON , listing ORG as defendant .
CARDINAL . On DATE , at the directions hearing , the defendants disclosed that they had acted on the orders of ORG ( ORG ) . The court joined the ORG as a co - defendant .

CARDINAL . On DATE the defendant requested that jurisdiction be transferred to ORG because matters involving ORG secrets could only be examined by regional courts . The court granted their request in an interim decision .

CARDINAL . On DATE , after repeated adjournments , the hearing was held in camera before ORG . The applicant and PERSON were represented by counsel and an officer of ORG in GPE , both of whom were required to give an undertaking not to disclose the contents of the proceedings .
CARDINAL . ORG dismissed the complaint . On the issue of whether the applicant had posed a threat to national security , the judgment stated as following :

“ The representative of the first deputy head of ORG , of ORG ... did not accept the appellants’ claims , and presented a written defence to the complaint ... In support of his position the representative pointed out that his client had approved the report to deny GPE citizen PERSON entry into GPE , which was prepared by ORG of ORG on the basis of materials obtained as a result of operational and search measures . In the opinion of NORP ORG experts participating in the preparation of the report , the [ applicant ’s ] activities in our country are of a destructive nature and pose a threat to the security of GPE . The representative ... emphasised that the threat to State security is created by the activities , not the religious beliefs of [ the applicant ] . ”

CARDINAL . Nowhere else in the CARDINAL - page text of the judgment did ORG indicate what “ activities ” had posed a threat to national security . It may , however , be inferred from the judgment that the applicant ’s phone conversations had been intercepted by the ORG pursuant to a certain earlier court order .

CARDINAL . It also appears that ORG examined an information letter from ORG of CARDINAL DATE , entitled “ Information on the activities of representatives of non - traditional religious associations on NORP territory ” , which stated , in particular , as follows :

“ Representatives of such foreign sectarian communities as the Jehovah ’s Witnesses , PERSON ’s ORG ... under the cover of religion establish extensive governing structures which they use for gathering socio - political , economic , military and other information about ongoing events in GPE , indoctrinate the citizens and incite separatist tendencies ... Missionary organisations purposefully work towards implementing the goals set by certain Western circles with a view to creating the conditions in GPE and perfecting the procedure for practical implementation of the idea of replacing the ‘ socio - psychological code’ of the population , which will automatically lead to the erasing from the people ’s memory of the over a DATE history of GPE and the questioning of such concepts as national self - identification , patriotism , GPE and spiritual heritage ... ”

CARDINAL . As to the applicant ’s TIME detention , the officers of ORG denied in court that the applicant had been “ detained ” and claimed that he had bought a ticket to GPE and merely waited for his flight scheduled for DATE . Although ORG established that the ticket had been in fact bought in TIME DATE , it held that this fact was “ of no legal significance ” and ruled that the applicant had not been deprived of his liberty .

CARDINAL . ORG also noted that the NORP authorities had not prevented the applicant from reuniting with his son in any country other than GPE . His allegations about interference with his family life were therefore rejected as manifestly ill - founded .

CARDINAL . The applicant appealed , citing as grounds , inter alia , that ORG had failed to examine whether the ORG had any legitimate basis in fact for its “ conclusions ” . He relied on LAW , DATE , DATE and CARDINAL of the Convention .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of GPE , sitting in camera in a CARDINAL - judge formation , dismissed the appeal . It held that there had been no violations of the applicant ’s Convention rights . The judgment was based on the administrative competence of the ORG and ORG to take decisions in the field of national security and border control . It did not indicate what activities of the applicant were alleged to pose a threat to national security :

“ The decision on the issue whether or not the activities of a citizen ( in respect of whom a conclusion barring entry into GPE has been issued ) pose a threat to State security ... comes within the competence of the NORP authorities ... this right of the ORG is one of the basic elements of its sovereignty . Therefore , the [ regional ] court ’s conclusion that the claims of the appellant and his representatives that ORG acted ultra vires are unfounded in the present case . ” [ so in the original ]

CARDINAL . A competent authority , such as ORG or ORG , may issue a decision that a foreign national ’s presence on NORP territory is undesirable . Such decision may be issued if a foreign national is unlawfully residing on NORP territory , or if his or her residence is lawful but creates a real threat to the defensive capacity or security of the ORG , to public order or health , etc . If such a decision has been given , the foreign national has to leave GPE or will otherwise be deported . The decision also forms the legal basis for subsequent refusal of re - entry into GPE ( section CARDINAL of the PERSON on the Procedure for Entering and Leaving GPE , no . CARDINAL-FZ of DATE , as amended on DATE – “ FAC ” ) .

CARDINAL . A foreign national will be refused entry into GPE if this is necessary for the purposes of ensuring the defensive capacity or security of the State , or protecting public order or health ( section QUANTITY of LAW ) .

CARDINAL . The Guidelines on checking the documents of persons crossing the border of GPE , ratified by order no . CARDINAL of ORG of DATE ( “ FAC ” ) , were not published or accessible to the public . The applicant submitted that they contained the following provisions , the authenticity of which was not disputed by the Government :

“ ... upon discovery of [ persons whose entry into GPE is prohibited ] , officials of the border control shall notify them of the grounds for refusing them entry across the border , escort them to isolated LOC and place them under guard , and take measures towards deportation of such persons from the territory of GPE . ”

CARDINAL . The ORG or regional treasury is liable – irrespective of any fault by ORG officials DATE for the damage sustained by an individual on account of , in particular , unlawful criminal prosecution or unlawful application of a preventive measure in the form of placement in custody ( Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW ) . A court may hold the tortfeasor liable for non - pecuniary damage incurred by an individual through actions impairing his or her personal non - property rights , such as the right to personal integrity and the right to liberty of movement ( Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW ) . Non - pecuniary damage must be compensated for irrespective of the tortfeasor ’s fault in the event of , in particular , unlawful conviction or prosecution or unlawful application of a preventive measure in the form of placement in custody ( LAW ) .
CARDINAL . The Explanatory Report to Protocol No . CARDINAL ( ETS No . CARDINAL ) defines the scope of application of LAW No . CARDINAL in the following manner :

“ CARDINAL . The word ‘ resident’ is intended to exclude from the application of the article any alien who has arrived at a port or other point of entry but has not yet passed through the immigration control or who has been admitted to the territory for the purpose only of transit or for a limited period for a non - residential purpose ...

The word lawfully refers to the domestic law of the ORG concerned . It is therefore for domestic law to determine the conditions which must be fulfilled for a person ’s presence in the territory to be considered ‘ lawful’ .

... [ A]n alien whose admission and stay were subject to certain conditions , for example a fixed period , and who no longer complies with these conditions can not be regarded as being still ‘ lawfully’ present . ”
CARDINAL . The ORG further cites definitions of the notion of “ lawful residence ” contained in other international instruments :

“ a. Residence by an alien in the territory of any of the Contracting Parties shall be considered lawful within the meaning of this Convention so long as there is in force in his case a permit or such other permission as is required by the laws and regulations of the country concerned to reside therein ...
b. Lawful residence shall become unlawful from the date of any deportation order made out against the person concerned , unless a stay of execution is granted . ”

“ a. Regulations governing the admission , residence and movement of aliens and also their right to engage in gainful occupations shall be unaffected by this Convention insofar as they are not inconsistent with it ;
b. Nationals of a Contracting Party shall be considered as lawfully residing in the territory of another ORG if they have conformed to the said regulations . ”
CARDINAL . The ORG clarifies the notion of “ expulsion ” as follows :

“ CARDINAL . The concept of expulsion is used in a generic sense as meaning any measure compelling the departure of an alien from the territory but does not include extradition . Expulsion in this sense is an autonomous concept which is independent of any definition contained in domestic legislation . Nevertheless , for the reasons explained in paragraph CARDINAL above , it does not apply to the refoulement of aliens who have entered the territory unlawfully , unless their position has been subsequently regularised .

CARDINAL . Paragraph CARDINAL of this article provides first that the person concerned may be expelled only ‘ in pursuance of a decision reached in accordance with law’ . No exceptions may be made to this rule . However , again , ‘ law’ refers to the domestic law of the ORG concerned . The decision must therefore be taken by the competent authority in accordance with the provisions of substantive law and with the relevant procedural rules . ”
